name: White-Veined Dutchman's Pipe
description: Aristolochia fimbriata, commonly known as White-Veined Dutchman's Pipe or Fringed Dutchman's Pipe, is a perennial climbing plant native to South America, particularly Brazil, Paraguay, Bolivia, Uruguay, and Argentina. It belongs to the Aristolochiaceae family and features heart-shaped to kidney-shaped, dark green leaves (5-10 cm long) with prominent white veins. The plant produces distinctive, pipe-shaped flowers (2-4 cm long) that are white to cream-colored with purple-brown markings and fringed margins. The flowering plant attracts butterflies and is known for its traditional medicinal properties. The plant displays a climbing or trailing growth habit and can reach lengths of 1-2 meters. In its native habitat, it grows as a climbing vine in tropical and subtropical forests. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds unique interest with its distinctive flowers and climbing habit.
